did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia building records

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to the buildings owned and occupied by the Library Company. Items include reports and correspondence regarding the construction of and move to the Ridgway building at 13th and Locust; correspondence about and blueprints, deeds, and settlement documents for the Juniper and Locust property; deeds and correspondence related to several properties owned by the Library Company; and blueprints and schematics for the main Library Company building on Locust, as well as flat and rolled blueprints for 1982 and 1992 renovations to the building. The collection also includes a volume of blueprints for 1938 modifications to the Ridgway Branch building at Broad and Christian Streets; two copies of a 1988 planning and feasibility study for the disposition of the Furness building; and photos and negatives of buildings and renovation projects.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
